tossups.question: In this play, a character who sings about “the wind and the rain” imitates a priest named Sir Topas to torture another character. That steward is tricked into donning yellow cross garters and smiling by a letter ostensibly written by a noblewoman who falls in love with a messenger. In this play, that messenger, who goes by the alias Cesario, works for a man who opens this play by saying (*) “If music be the food of love, play on!” and longs for Olivia. This play ends with the marriage of Duke Orsino and the crossdressing main character. For 10 points, name this Shakespearean comedy set in Illyria featuring the shipwrecked twins Viola and Sebastian.

A substance secreted by the type II cells of structures in this organ contain the phospholipid DPPC. Though not the kidney, angiotensin-converting enzyme is found in the capillaries of this organ. This organ is surrounded by the pleural membrane. Stacks of hemolymph-containing tissue in (*) arachnids compose the “book” form of this organ. The function of this organ is tested using a spirometer. This organ begins at the trachea and branches from bronchi to alveolar sacs. Deoxygenated blood is carried to this organ from the heart via the pulmonary artery. For ten points, name this primary organ in the human respiratory system.

This instrument plays a solo evocative of a bird call soon after a transition to G major in the first movement of Antonin Dvořák’s Symphony No. 8. The second entry in Claude Debussy’s Six Sonatas for Various Instruments was written for this instrument, viola, and harp. A symphonic poem that marked a transition to modern music opens with a solo for this instrument that begins on a C-sharp before (*) chromatically descending to a G; that piece, also by Debussy, is Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun. The piccolo is a higher-pitched variant of this instrument. For ten points, name this reedless woodwind instrument that is held sideways.

A version of “All Is Found” recorded by this artist is played during the end credits of Frozen II. In one song, this artist gives advice on what to do “when the straight and narrow/gets a little too straight.” That song, “Follow Your Arrow,” appears alongside “Silver Lining” and “Merry Go Round” on this singer’s debut album, Same Trailer Different Park. In a song from a recent album, this artist sings (*) “Born in a hurry/always late/haven’t been early since ‘88.” “Slow Burn” and “Space Cowboy” appear on a 2018 album by this artist, which won the 2019 Grammy award for Best Album of the Year. For ten points, name this singer of Golden Hour.

This ruler’s chaplain Rodriguez de Fonseca was appointed to form a colonial bureaucracy, laying the foundation for the Council of the Indies. This monarch succeeded Henry IV after defeating Joanna la Beltraneja at the Battle of Toro. This ruler was often advised by Tomas de Torquemada, who headed an institution set up by this monarch and her (*) husband which often conducted auto-da-fe ceremonies. Jews were expelled from this queen’s country in the Alhambra Decree, and she ended the Reconquista by taking Granada from the Moors. For ten points, name this queen of Spain who sponsored the voyages of Christopher Columbus with her husband Ferdinand of Aragon.

Queen Teuta led a group of these people from Illyria who used lembos, and the Qing dynasty fought a group of these people led by Ching Shih. Edward D’Oyley invited some of these people to defend his city and often gave them letters of marque to do so. Mary Read and Anne Bonny worked with one of these people, (*) Calico Jack Rackham. Christopher Myngs and Henry Morgan, two of these people, lived in Port Royal, a haven for many of these people. An early version of the Jolly Roger flag was used by one of these people named Blackbeard. For ten points, name these naval raiders, who looted cargo and treasure during their namesake “Golden Age.”
tossups.answer: pirates [accept corsairs, buccaneers, privateers, and other equivalents]
acceptable: corsairs, buccaneers, privateers, and other equivalents

tossups.question: The steady-state approximation assumes that this quantity for intermediates remains constant. It’s not path length, but absorbance is proportional to this quantity by Beer’s law. Increasing this non-dimensionless quantity causes the freezing point of a mixture to decrease. This quantity is denoted using (*) square brackets. For an aqueous reaction, values of this quantity for different species are raised to stoichiometric coefficients to calculate the equilibrium constant. Common measures of this quantity are molarity and molality. For ten points, name this quantity that represents the amount of solute per unit solvent.
tossups.answer: concentration [accept molarity or molality until they are mentioned]

tossups.question: One character in this work never shows her face in public because of her large nose, but the protagonist is still attracted by her zither playing. The protagonist of this work begins a relationship with the Lady of the Orange Blossoms. During a festival, the title character of this work gives a perfect performance of a dance called  the “Waves of the (*) Blue Sea.” One chapter in this work is left blank, implying that the title character has died, and is titled “Vanished Into the Clouds.” For ten points, name this medieval Japanese novel by Murasaki Shikibu about a prince who has many lovers.
tossups.answer: The Tale of Genji [or Genji No Monogatari]

tossups.question: A princess of this city was kidnapped after her father refused to give a set of magical horses to Heracles. Brutus, the mythical founder of Britain, was descended from a prince of this city who once battled Turnus for the hand of Lavinia. Apollo and Poseidon built the walls of this city while serving its king, Laomedon. The infant (*) Astyanax was killed by Neoptolemus, who in some depictions used the dead body to kill its king Priam. After a ten-year siege, this city fell when it accepted a certain gift devised by Odysseus, known as its namesake “horse.” For ten points, name this city that warred with the Greeks in Homer’s Iliad.

A nickname given to this politician stems from an allegation that his father-in-law’s shipping company had attempted to smuggle drugs into Colombia. Charles Booker lost to a former Marine pilot in a primary to face this politician in a 2020 general election. This politician called themselves the “Grim Reaper” of (*) progressive legislation after defeating a slew of 2018 and 2019 Democratic initiatives. This man, who succeeded Harry Reid to reach his highest office, defeated Amy McGrath in an election in November 2020. “Cocaine” sometimes precedes the name of, for ten points, what Senate Minority Leader and senior Senator from Kentucky?

The symmetric group of degree 3 is the smallest group whose operation does not possess this property, and the operations for all cyclic groups have this property. If an operation possesses this property, then a group under that operation is called abelian. The cross product has the “anti” form of this property, as does multiplication of quaternions. This property is not present in (*) matrix multiplication. This property does not generally hold for subtraction and division, since reversing the order produces a different result. For ten points, identify this property that, for addition, implies a plus b equals b plus a.
tossups.answer: commutativity [accept commutative; accept abelian until it is mentioned]

tossups.question: In one movie set during this event, a character nicknamed Gomer Pyle is chastised for hiding a jelly donut before eventually killing himself and his superior in a bathroom. In the second half of that film, the correspondent Joker kills a young girl at the direction of the sadistic Animal Mother. Another film set during this event ends with (*) Colonel Kurtz crying, "The horror! The horror!" That film set during this war sets a helicopter attack to Wagner's Ride of the Valkyries and features a character wistfully stating that he “[loves] the smell of napalm in the morning.” For ten points, name this 1960s war, the setting of Full Metal Jacket and Apocalypse Now.

In Nordic countries, it is traditional to read or watch murder mysteries during this event, and in Hungary, a delicacy known as sargaturo is eaten on this day. A Holy Fire is said to miraculously appear and light up candles and lamps in the Church of the Holy Sepulchre the night before this event. In Catholicism, large candles marked with the letters Alpha and Omega are lit on this holiday. This holiday’s date is no longer determined by the date of (*) Passover. This celebration, which occurs two days after Good Friday, marks the end of lent. For ten points, what holiday that commemorates the resurrection of Jesus is often associated with painted eggs?

Justice Felix Frankfurter wrote an Atlantic Monthly article calling for the retrial of convicts of this ethnicity. People of this ethnicity assisted the U.S. government in carrying out Operation Husky. A politician of this ethnicity co-sponsored a bill banning yellow-dog contracts with George Norris, and was nicknamed the “Little Flower.” A double-murder at a shoe factory in (*) Braintree, Massachusetts was carried out by two anarchists of this ethnicity who were electrocuted in 1927. New York mayor Fiorello LaGuardia and Sacco and Vanzetti were members of, for ten points, what ethnic group whose members often immigrated from places like Sicily?

This male coauthor of the play Mule Bone wrote a poem in which the speaker describes liking "a pipe for a Christmas present" after his teacher tells him to "Go home and write a page tonight." In addition to a poem where the speaker likes "Bessie, bop, or Bach," "Theme for (*) English B," this author wrote a poem whose speaker sees places like the Nile and Euphrates and notes that his soul has grown deep like them and a poem where a concept "dries up like a raisin in the sun." For ten points, name this Harlem Renaissance poet of The Negro Speaks of Rivers and about "a dream deferred" in "Harlem."

A collection of point particles with nonzero values of this quantity cannot exist in stable stationary equilibrium by Earnshaw’s theorem. The magnetic force on a particle is given by this quantity times the cross product of the particle’s velocity and the magnetic field. The flux through a closed surface is proportional to the amount of this quantity enclosed by (*) Gauss’s Law. This quantity is uniformly distributed over the surface of a conductor. The force between objects with nonzero values of this quantity is given by an inverse-square law named for Coulomb. For ten points, name this electrical quantity measured in Coulombs.

The art of the Kwakiutl tribe includes one of these objects named for Hamatsa, or the Raven-cannibal. A golden one of these objects may have been fraudulently placed at a dig site by its discoverer, Heinrich Schliemann. Omote, an example of these objects, are frequently used in Japanese (*) Noh theatre. Charles de Lorme invented a type of these things resembling a bird, which was not actually used by doctors during the Black Plague. Two of these items representing comedy and tragedy are frequently used as a symbol of the theatre. For ten points, name these items used to cover faces.
tossups.answer: masks [accept burial masks, ceremonial masks, death masks, or any other kind of mask]
tossups.answer_formatted: masks [accept burial masks, ceremonial masks, death masks, or any other kind of mask]
acceptable: burial masks, ceremonial masks, death masks,

tossups.question: A manual on how to use this technology is found in the Huolongjing [Huo-long-jing]. The making of this product required garlic, according to a text called the Wujing Zongyao [Wu-jing Zong-yao], which is the earliest source providing instructions for creating this substance. The Safavid, Mughal, and (*) Ottoman empires are known as this substance’s namesake “empires.” Along with the compass, printing, and paper, this substance is often listed as one of the Four Great Inventions of China. This substance was likely discovered while attempting to use saltpeter and sulfur to create the elixir of life, causing an unexpected explosion. For ten points, name this explosive substance used in firearms.

A poem in the form of one of these things by Alexander Pope asks “Who breaks a butterfly upon a wheel?” A Montesquieu novel that follows Usbek and Rica as they travel through France is titled for the “Persian” type of these items. These things, which provide the structure of The Sorrows of Young Werther, document the Arctic explorer Robert Walton’s conversations with the title character in (*) Frankenstein. One of these documents sent from Lucy Westenra to Mina Harker discusses three marriage proposals. This type of communication provides the structure of epistolary novels, like Dracula. For ten points, name these written messages, generally delivered by mail.
tossups.answer: letters [accept epistle, accept epistolary novel, accept Epistle to Doctor Arbuthnot, accept Persian Letters]
tossups.answer_formatted: letters [accept epistle, or epistolary novel, or Epistle to Doctor Arbuthnot, or Persian Letters]

tossups.question: The subject of the documentary Sculpting the Wind, Alexa King, created a statue outside Churchill Downs that memorializes one of these animals. The Thunder Stone serves as a pedestal for a bronze statue of one of these animals, created by Etienne [it-yen] Maurice [more-eess] Falconet [falcon-ay] in (*) St. Petersburg. Theodore Roosevelt owned a small statue of one of these animals, sculpted by Frederic Remington. A Donatello statue that includes one of these animals may depict Erasmo da Narni. That statue, the Gattamelata, depicts a man riding one of these animals. For ten points, name these animals depicted in equestrian statues.
tossups.answer: horses [accept equus ferus caballus, accept broncos, accept equestrian statues before mention]
tossups.answer_formatted: horses [accept equus ferus caballus, or broncos,accept equestrian statues before mention]

tossups.question: While trying to capture this city, Charles Grey committed the “Paoli Massacre” in the nearby city of Malvern. George Washington lost at Germantown during the Revolutionary War campaign named for this city. In an attempt to avoid war, the Olive Branch petition was drafted by a legislative body in this city. In the winter of 1777, (*) Baron von Steuben trained American troops at Valley Forge outside this city. This city’s Independence Hall served as the meeting place of the Second Continental Congress. The Declaration of Independence was signed in, for ten points, what most populous city in Pennsylvania?

bonuses.leadin: The Reynolds number is the ratio of inertial forces to forces related to this quantity. For ten points each:
parts: Name this quantity that is constant for a Newtonian fluid. The drag force acting on a sphere moving through a fluid is proportional to radius, velocity, and this quantity.
Viscosity commonly comes in dynamic and kinematic forms, which differ by a factor given by this other quantity for a fluid. This quantity is commonly defined as mass divided by volume.

When the viscosity of a fluid is zero, this set of equations governing fluid dynamics simplifies to the Euler equations. The existence and smoothness for the 3-dimensional solution to these equations is the subject of a Millenium Prize problem.

bonuses.leadin: Many works of literature gained significance in American history outside of their literary value. For ten points each:
parts: This author stoked abolitionist sentiments with her novel featuring the wicked Simon Legree. When Lincoln met this author, he allegedly said “So you’re the little lady who wrote the book that started this big war,” a reference to her novel Uncle Tom’s Cabin.
Henry David Thoreau’s Civil Disobedience highlighted his refusal to pay taxes to support this war. James Lowell’s “The Biglow Papers” satirized this war, criticizing generals like Zachary Taylor.

In Ford’s Theater, Abraham Lincoln was watching this play when John Wilkes Booth shot him. Booth timed his shot to coincide with this play’s line “you sockdologizing old man-trap” because he thought the laughter would mask his gunshot.

bonuses.leadin: This style’s namesake “beat” was derived from samba music. For ten points each:
answers: guitar [accept acoustic guitar or electric guitar]
parts: Name this style of music that originated in Brazil in the 1950s. This style, whose name translates to “new wave,” was popularized internationally by Stan Getz and Antônio Carlos Jobim.
Like the samba music it derived from, bossa nova players frequently used their fingers rather than a pick to play this six-stringed instrument, which comes in acoustic and electric varieties.

This song, most famously recorded by Stan Getz and Astrud and João Gilberto, brought bossa nova to the forefront of American pop music. The title figure of this song is described as “tall and tan and young and lovely” as she walks to the sea, ignoring those around her.

bonuses.leadin: In a photograph by Man Ray, this woman wears a velvet hat and a fur trimmed coat. For ten points each:
parts: Name this female alter ego of the artist behind Nude Descending a Staircase, No. 2. In the title of a sculpture featuring marble cubes and a cuttlefish bone in a birdcage, she is asked “Why Not Sneeze?”
Rrose Sélavy was a pseudonym used by this French-American Dada artist. One of his “readymades” features a urinal signed “R. Mutt.” and is titled Fountain.
Another one of Duchamp’s “readymades” is titled L.H.O.O.Q. [el-ahsh-oh-oh-koo], which parodies the Mona Lisa by adding this unusual facial feature.

bonuses.leadin: This poet wrote about the wind “ruffling the tawny pelt” of the title continent in “A Far Cry From Africa.” For ten points each:
answers: grapes [accept Sea Grapes, accept Grapes of Wrath]
parts: Name this Saint Lucian author who wrote the poem The Star-Apple Kingdom, the play Dream on Monkey Mountain, and a retelling of the Iliad in Omeros.
In one scene in Omeros, Helen walks on the beach singing this band’s song Yesterday. That song by this British quartet was written by Paul McCartney.
In a poem named for the “Sea” type of these fruits, Walcott wrote that “the classics can console/but not enough.” A novel titled for these fruits features the preacher Jim Casy.

bonuses.leadin: An oceanic circulation system often referred to as the “ocean conveyor belt” is named for this quantity and salinity. For ten points each:
answers: El Niño [accept El Niño-Southern Oscillation or ENSO; do not accept or prompt on “La Niña”]
parts: Name this quantity that is slowly increasing as a result of greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere. This quantity is often measured in degrees Celsius.
This periodic climate phenomenon causes the sea surface temperature in the Eastern Pacific to increase. During this phenomenon, trade winds across the Pacific typically weaken or reverse direction.
During El Niño events, the strength of this process is reduced on the South American coast. This process is primarily driven by wind, the Coriolis effect and Ekman transport.
answers_formatted: El Niño [accept El Niño-Southern Oscillation or ENSO; do not accept or prompt on "“La Niña”"]

bonuses.leadin: In this short story, one of the protagonists buys an item for $21 after selling a certain item to Madame Sofronie. For ten points each:
parts: Name this short story. In this story, Della sells her hair to buy a watch chain, only to find that her husband Jim has sold his watch to buy hair combs.
“The Gift of the Magi” is by this American author, who published it along with several other stories in his collection The Four Million. This author also wrote “The Ransom of Red Chief.”

This story included in The Four Million features the criminal Soapy’s failed efforts to escape the cold New York winter by getting sent to prison. However, after he decides to turn his life around, he is arrested for loitering.

bonuses.leadin: The Five Pillars of Islam form the foundation of Muslim life and practice. For ten points each:
parts: One of the pillars is known as the hajj, where able-bodied Muslims are expected to make the pilgrimage to this holiest city in Islam. Rituals performed here include walking seven times around the Kaaba.
This pillar dictates that fasting should take place during the month of Ramadan, during which Muslims must abstain from food and drink from dawn to dusk.
To follow the instructions of this pillar, Muslims usually donate about 2.5% of their individual income. Curiously enough, this pillar is not found in the Quran, but instead in the hadith.

bonuses.leadin: This commander’s nickname stemmed either from the color of his shield or his merciless treatment to those he conquered. For ten points each:
answers: Edward the Black Prince [accept the Black Prince, accept Edward of Woodstock, prompt on Edward alone]
parts: Name this English knight who won the Battle of Poitiers, forcing the French to sign the unfavorable Treaty of Poitiers. Although he was never king, this man’s son Richard II would inherit the throne the year after his passing.
Edward the Black Prince was a commander during this lengthy conflict that resulted in a French Valois victory. Despite this conflict’s name, in reality it spanned an extra 16 years until 1453.

Despite ultimately losing the conflict, the English won numerous battles, including this victory for Henry V where longbowmen proved to be a key factor against the heavy cavalry commanded by Charles d'Albret.
answers_formatted: Edward the Black Prince [accept the Black Prince, or Edward of Woodstock, prompt on Edward alone]
acceptable: Edward of Woodstock, prompt on Edward alone

bonuses.leadin: In a work co-authored by this philosopher, he spends hundreds of pages proving that one plus one equals two. For ten points each,
parts: Name this philosopher who published Principia Mathematica with Alfred Whitehead. In the article “Is There a God?”, this thinker proposed his “teapot” analogy.
Bertrand Russell mentored this other Austrian philosopher, and wrote the introduction to his Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus.
Wittgenstein later wrote this other work in which he proposed a thought experiment about a beetle-in-a-box to show that private languages are incoherent.

bonuses.leadin: This composer depicted the months of the year in the cycle Das Jahr [yar]. For ten points each:
answers: Fanny (Cäcilie) Mendelssohn Bartholdy [prompt on Mendelssohn or F. Mendelssohn]
United Kingdom [prompt on Great Britain or England]
parts: Name this composer of the Easter Sonata. This composer inspired and likely co-wrote some of the Songs Without Words composed by her brother, Felix.

While on a trip to this country, Felix Mendelssohn performed his song Italien for Queen Victoria and admitted that it was actually composed by Fanny. Felix was also inspired by this nation’s constituent country, Scotland, for his Hebrides Overture.
On account of their Jewish heritage, Felix and Fanny Mendelssohn were attacked by this German composer of the operas Parsifal and Tristan und Isolde in his anti-Semitic tract “Jewishness in Music.”

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about geography… in the Roman world:
answers: Switzerland [or Swiss Confederation, accept Confédération Suisse, Confederazione Svizzera, Confederaziun svizra, Schweizerische Eidgenossenschaft, or Confoederatio Helvetica]
parts: The two halves of this Hungarian capital city, which was known to the Romans as Aquincum, are united by the Szechenyi [say-chain-ee] Chain Bridge.

The Roman provinces of Helvetia and Raetia make up most of this modern-day country. During the Crisis of the Third Century, the Alemanni took control of most of this modern day country, causing Valentinian to fortify its city of Basel.
Conquered by Mithridates VI, the Roman province of Pontus in Anatolia got its name from this body of water. This body of water was known by the Romans as the Pontus Euxinus.
answers_formatted: Switzerland [or Swiss Confederation, accept Confédération Suisse, Confederazione Svizzera, Confederaziun svizra, Schweizerische Eidgenossenschaft, or Confoederatio Helvetica]
acceptable: Swiss Confederation, accept Confédération Suisse, Confederazione Svizzera, Confederaziun svizra, Schweizerische Eidgenossenschaft,

bonuses.leadin: Jacques Monod and François Jacob won the Nobel Prize in Physiology for observing this system. For ten points each:
answers: lac operon [or lactose operon; prompt on operon]
parts: Name this genetic system that contains A, Y, and Z genes. This system, the first prokaryotic gene regulation system to be understood, enables bacteria to metabolize its namesake sugar.
Another operon, the trp [trip] operon, is named for tryptophan, one of these compounds. These compounds, which also include serine and methionine, are the monomers that make up proteins.
Jacob and Monod’s experiments were done on this model organism, where the lac operon was discovered. The Shiga toxin-producing variety of this bacterium can cause food poisoning.

bonuses.leadin: You can’t count how many times Jenny rejected the advances of this character. For ten points each:
parts: Name this Lincoln Pierce-created doodler who is a sixth grader at PS 38. He is often found with his best friends Teddy and Francis or in the detention room with Mrs. Czerwicki.

Perhaps the most notable teacher at PS 38 is this social studies teacher, who assigns Nate the most detentions. Nate spends much of his time making up nicknames for her such as “Godzilla” or “She who must Not be named”
To the confusion of his family, Nate is known for his skill in this board game, which is played with bishops, queens, and knights.

bonuses.leadin: The giant Geryon had three heads, and according to some sources, three bodies. For ten points each:
parts: During his tenth labor, this hero killed Geryon using an arrow dipped in the blood of the Hydra, and then stole his cattle. This hero’s other feats include defeating the Nemean Lion and capturing the Erymanthian Boar.

While Heracles was searching for Geryon and his cattle, he shot this god, but then apologized and received a golden cup that this god used to sail across the sky. In another myth, this god’s son Phaethon dies while trying to control a chariot.
This two-headed dog helped to guard Geryon’s cattle. Heracles killed this dog using his club.

bonuses.leadin: This work also contains the closet drama Samson Agonistes. For ten points each,
answers: Paradise Regained [do not accept or prompt on “Paradise Lost”]
blindness [accept blind or other equivalents of being unable to see]
parts: Name this poem in which Jesus wanders the desert for 40 days and Satan continually offers him food, which he refuses. This poem is the sequel to a 1667 poem that features fallen angels building the city of Pandemonium.

Paradise Regained is by this English poet, who wrote about Satan planning Adam and Eve’s expulsion from Eden in Paradise Lost. He also wrote the pastoral elegy “Lycidas,” dedicated to his friend Edward King.

In Paradise Lost, Satan awakes in Hell and sees nothing but “darkness visible,” a possible reference to this condition that afflicted Milton. His sonnet “When I consider how my light is spent” is about this ailment.
answers_formatted: Paradise Regained [do not accept or prompt on "“Paradise Lost”"]
blindness [accept blind or other equivalents of being unable to see]
acceptable: other equivalents of being unable to see

bonuses.leadin: A series of strikes known as the “Hot Autumn” is generally considered to be one of the inciting events of this period. For ten points each:
answers: Years of Lead [or anni di piombo]
parts: Name this period of civil unrest during the 1970s and 1980s. During this period, a far-left group known as the Red Brigades kidnapped and killed former prime minister Aldo Moro.
The Years of Lead occurred in this European country. During it, policeman Antonio Annarumma was killed by far-left demonstrators in this country’s city of Milan.

Members of the Red Brigades also assassinated Leamon Hunt, a diplomat from this country. During World War II, the chief of staff of a general from this nation accepted the Italian surrender to the Allies, months after that general led Allied forces in Operation Torch.

bonuses.leadin: The Vigreux column is an example of this type of laboratory apparatus that consists of a wide tube with multiple “glass fingers.” For ten points each:
parts: Name these laboratory tools commonly used in reflux to convert vapor into liquid. The simplest of these devices consists of a straight glass tube angled downwards, which uses the surrounding air to cool the analyte.
Condensers are used in this procedure that separates a mixture based on the boiling points of its constituents. This procedure has a “fractional” variant that is used to refine petroleum.
Distillation is effective when the mixture obeys this law, which relates the partial pressure of a mixture’s components to their vapor pressures. Azeotropes are mixtures that deviate from this law.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about the play Nathan the Wise:
parts: The play’s central message of religious tolerance takes its central parable from the story of three rings representing the three major religions, which also appears in this collection of tales told by a group of people fleeing a plague in a Florentine villa, written by Giovanni Boccaccio.
Gotthold Ephraim Lessing, the author of the play, was from what is now this country. Other playwrights from this country wrote works such as The Robbers and Spring Awakening.

In Nathan the Wise, the title character is an incredibly generous Jewish moneylender. A less flattering depiction of a Jewish moneylender is this Venetian character from an earlier play, who demands a pound of flesh from Antonio after he cannot pay back his loan.

bonuses.leadin: A series of revolts of these people in the 1970s in Thailand, led by the FFT, ended in failure. For ten points each:
answers: Zapatista Army of National Liberation [accept Ejército Zapatista de Liberación Nacional]
Commonwealth of the Philippines [accept Commonwealth de Filipinas, accept Komonwelt ng Pilipinas]
parts: Name this general class of poor labourers. In 1381, Wat Tyler led a rebellion of these people in England.
Indigenous peasants, known as campesinos, participated in a 1994 uprising in Chiapas led by this group. This group, which protested the ratification of NAFTA, was led by Subcomandante Marcos.

The 1942 Hukbalahap rebellion in this country was notable for the prominent role of women peasants in the movement. The rebellion, which was centered in this country’s region of Luzon, got its name from a Tagalog acronym for People’s Anti-Japanese Army.
answers_formatted: Zapatista Army of National Liberation [accept Ejército Zapatista de Liberación Nacional]
Commonwealth of the Philippines [accept Commonwealth de Filipinas, or Komonwelt ng Pilipinas]
